title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: MattN noticed a problem with the WIP patch from bug 469443 applied.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: When typing in the search box, sometimes search-suggestion entries would be displayed above the divider (where entries for previous matching searches are).

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: The problem here is that nsSearchSuggestions.js is passing the wrong previousResult to form history.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Instead of it being the previous form history search result, it's the SuggestAutoCompleteResult result (which contains the union of the form-history and search-suggest entries).

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: So, when form history refines its results as you time, it can actually add *more* entries as data leaks from the suggestions result into form history result, and it thus looks like the divider is being drawn in the wrong place.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: This bug wasn't visible before 469443, because nsFormFillController::StartSearch tries to QI the provided result to a nsIAutoCompleteSimpleResult.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: The search-suggestion result is only implements nsIAutoCompletResult (no \"Simple\"), so the QI fails, historyResult nee previousResult becomes null, and thus Satchel was doing a new search every time.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: EG:

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: 1) type \"b\" in the search field.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: 2) form history finds 1 entry (\"blah\"), search-suggestions finds \"baaa\", \"bloop\", \"bzzz\", the autocompete menu shows these in order with a divider between \"blah\" and \"baaa\".

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: 3) type an \"l\" in the search field (\"bl\")

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: 4) startHistorySearch()'s previous result contains [\"blah\", \"baaa\", \"bloop\", \"bzzz\"], Satchel filters this down to [\"blah\", \"bloop\"] to match the new \"bl\" search string

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: 5) nsSearchSuggestions's onReadyState() change is called with updated search suggestions, builds up a new list of results, but sees that the form history result now has *two* entries.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Created an attachment (id=380567) [details] Patch v.1 (WIP)

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: This fixes the problem, but isn't quite correct...

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: If you type \"a<backspace>b\", satchel trying to use the results from the \"a\" search for the \"b\" search, and so nothing is found.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: I suspect nsSearchSuggestions needs to throw away the old form history result when the search string changes like this, but I'm not entirely sure it's responsible for doing so, maybe satchel should be smarter about throwing away a previous result when the previous result's search string doesn't have a common prefix.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: [That seems to be handled somewhere else for normal form field entries, oddly enough.]

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Created an attachment (id=383211) [details] Patch v.2

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Ah. So, there's a ._formHistoryResult in the SuggestAutoCompleteResult wrapper (used to combine form history with search suggestions), and also a ._formHistoryResult in SuggestAutoComplete (the service itself, used to hold onto a form history result until a search suggestion is available).

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: The simple fix it to just discard the service's form history result copy when startSearch() is called with a null previous result.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Otherwise it's trying to use a old form history result that no longer applies for the search string.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: (From update of attachment 383211 [details])

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Perhaps we should rename one of them to _fhResult just to reduce confusion?

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: (In reply to comment #3)

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: > (From update of attachment 383211 [details] [details])

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: > Perhaps we should rename one of them to _fhResult just to reduce confusion?

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Good point.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: I renamed the one in the wrapper to _formHistResult.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: fhResult seemed maybe a bit too short.

title: "(495584) Firefox - search suggestions passes wrong previous result to form history"
sen: Pushed http://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/097598383614

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: That pref was thought to be for extensions which wanted to completely replace our own Session Restore functionality.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: While this has worked somehow for Tab Mix Plus, we've had several issues with people ending up both Session Restore and Tab Mix Plus disabled (see bug 435055 and its duplicates).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Furthermore, there are several code points which will also break when Session Restore has been disabled (such as the list of recently closed tabs).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Instead of adding try-catch-blocks wherever we use Session Restore, I'd much rather encourage extensions authors to override both nsSessionStartup and nsSessionStore to provide the same API with their own functionality (or implementing a dummy-API and making sure for themselves that they've correctly replaced all known consumers).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: This would also make the lives of those other extension authors simpler who so far can't be too sure that the Session Store component actually works (through whatever implementation).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Note that privacy concerned users will still be able to disable writing to sessionstore.js through the browser.sessionstore.resume_from_crash pref.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Created an attachment (id=332726) [details]

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: remove the pref

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: (note: bug 448725 should be wontfixed if this is fixed)

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Created an attachment (id=333820) [details]

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: remove (buggy) note from API comments

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: (From update of attachment 332726 [details])

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: a problem with this patch is that the session data is still stored in memory while the app is running, and by removing this pref, there's no way to disable that.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: some users do not want the recently-closed-tabs menu, and others don't want any session tracks stored in memory at all.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: (In reply to comment #4)

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: > some users do not want the recently-closed-tabs menu,

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: That's what browser.sessionstore.max_tabs_undo is for: setting it to 0 effectively disables the feature.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: > and others don't want any session tracks stored in memory at all.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Then again, we don't save any data that wouldn't be in memory, anyway, or do we?

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: I'd rather introduce a different pref or different means to cater the privacy sensitive users than have this half-baked cut-it-all pref which AFAICT so far has produced more issues than it's solved.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: (In reply to comment #5)

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: > Then again, we don't save any data that wouldn't be in memory, anyway, or do we?

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Fair point. I'm not sure.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: > I'd rather introduce a different pref or different means to cater the privacy sensitive users than have this half-baked cut-it-all pref which AFAICT so far has produced more issues than it's solved.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Yes, agreed the pref is not ideal for this purpose.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: So max_tabs_undo=0 + resume_from_crash=false is fine for now, until proper \"private browsing\" is supported.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Pushed as 17120:e712e96d7861 and 17121:adb1ef78dd21.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: onemen: This patch significantly affects Tab Mix Plus:

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Instead of disabling SessionStore, you'll now have to replace it by shipping a component which implements the same API.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: You should be able to keep that component minimal, though, and just call your own code whenever the API is used.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: This will make the lives of people using the SessionStore API (such as Session Manager) somewhat simpler, as they can just use the API without having to worry too much about the implementation behind it.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: If you want to offer the option of switching between your and our implementation, see e.g. the ignore-history component of the Torbutton extension for how to overwrite a component with the original still being available internally (so that you can either pass API calls forward or handle them yourself).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Sounds like this has impact for extension authors and so should be documented on MDC

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: no problem.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: current Tabmix dev-build already not disable SessionStore

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: I currently have only one problem , how to disable the restore after restart.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: can you add a pref for this, or some other way to do it?

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: (In reply to comment #12)

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: > I currently have only one problem , how to disable the restore after restart.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: You've got several options for that:

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: * Set the prefs browser.sessionstore.resume_from_crash and browser.sessionstore.resume_session_once both to false as early as possible and make sure that browser.startup.page isn't 3.

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: * Delete the file sessionstore.js as early as possible (e.g. when the profile-after-change notification is dispatched).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: * For Firefox 3.1: Respond to the sessionstore-state-read notification by setting the subject's data member to an empty string (cf. bug 448741 comment#6).

title: "(449596) Firefox -  remove the browser.sessionstore.enabled pref "
sen: Or is there a use case I'm missing?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I've noticed that I frequently trigger the rotate gesture accidentally, usually while scrolling.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Gestures have improved since the original landing (when triggering the wrong gesture was really easy), but this articular gesture is still problematic.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: The basic reasoning is that it's highly disruptive to be switched to another tab when you're not expecting it.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: When it happens, you don't know what just happened until you notice that you're on some entirely different page, that's randomly to the left or right (1 or more tabs) from the page you thought you were on.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I'm don't think the rotate gesture for switching tabs is nearly as useful, discoverable, or a good fit as the other gestures are.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: So, given this problem, we should just disable it for 3.5.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: [I'd also be open to tweaking it to make it much harder to trigger accidentally, dunno if that's possible.]

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: See also bug 461376.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Just play around with browser.gesture.twist.* in about:config as a temporary workaround.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Justin, the odd thing here is that I find I trigger zoom more frequently than tab rotate ... far far more frequently.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: And I also find that it's not just in Firefox, it's all over OSX.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I wonder how much of this is us vs. odd timings causing misreads of the trackpad by OSX.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I think I've never accidentally switched tab because of rotate gesture.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Actually I'd probably decrease the default threshold for tab switching.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I've triggered zoom repeatedly too;

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: usually I fix it right away but a quick browse though content-prefs.sqlite shows ~20 sites with zoom settings that I didn't know were set.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: That's probably because zoom is a subtle effect (for 1 step, relative to the distraction that an accidental tab switch causes).

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: While playing with different browser.gesture.twist settings, I've found twisting through tabs often resulted in triggering a zoom.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Probably because a twist is a very awkward gesture to make, especially if it's more than a quarter-turn...

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Around that point, my fingers want to spread or join, and that ends up read as a pinch.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I guess that's part of why I'm not really fond of this gesture, and would just as soon turn it off.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I'll try running with a threshold of 40, but I suspect there's an unavoidable conflict between making it easy to use on purpose, yet hard to invoke accidentally.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I've been using swipe left/right to change tabs and cmd-left/right to go back/forward, but I do have rotate as change tabs as well and I haven't accidentally triggered it.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Maybe it's your rotating technique ;)

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I'm right handed and I position my index finger at 7oclock and ring finger at 1oclock.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: To rotate right I end up at 8/2oclocks.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: The first time I came into contact with tab switching via gesture was accidentally.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I wasn't sure what happened, I just appeared on another tab and couldn't figure out why.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: The tab-switching gesture right now isn't obvious and feels unexpected when I hit it.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Mardak: the way you've written this code, disabling the gesture is a pref-flip, right?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Blocking here for decision and mulling, will probably take it though.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Yup, should be able to just unset the default value for the twist prefs:

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: -pref(\"browser.gesture.twist.right\", \"Browser:NextTab\");

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: -pref(\"browser.gesture.twist.left\", \"Browser:PrevTab\");

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Would setting the value to empty-string (\"\") work, or something similar?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: It would be nice to leave the prefs visible for those who want to use them.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Since this is now implemented on Win7 with Multitouch screens please be sure not to disable it for Windows.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: (In reply to comment #10)

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: > Since this is now implemented on Win7 with Multitouch screens please be sure not to disable it for Windows.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Fine by me; though I'd be a bit wary of having Windows users hit the same problem with multitouch trackpads...

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: But Rob says such hardware/drivers doesn't exist today, so it shouldn't be a common problem.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: We should keep on eye out for problems with issues on touchscreens, andt from Rob demoing it on his touchscreen it would appear harder to trigger.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: And maybe Windows 7 is just better at discriminating between gestures.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: OTOH it wouldn't be a big deal to just disable it globally.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Safari doesn't use it, and Rob confirmed that IE doesn't use it on Windows 7.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: This bug is just rotate, but do we want to consider pinching too?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: If we take those out, we'll have swipe up/down as jump to top/bottom and swipe left/right as back/forward by default.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: (In reply to comment #12)

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: > This bug is just rotate, but do we want to consider pinching too?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Maybe; it certainly has been noted that people are accidentally hitting that gesture too.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Though I think it's a separate decision: rotate is an unnatural gesture for switching tabs (nothing else uses it this way), with a high penalty for accidentally triggering.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Pinching is a natural gesture for page zoom (and more widely used/known), with a low penalty for accidentally triggering.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: I think most people would consider it a bug if we claimed to support multitouch, but pinch didn't do anything.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: So, I'd strongly lean towards only removing the rotate. Pinchy would've wanted it this way.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: (In reply to comment #12)

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: > This bug is just rotate, but do we want to consider pinching too?

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: >

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: > If we take those out, we'll have swipe up/down as jump to top/bottom and swipe left/right as back/forward by default.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: pinch should definitely be left on for win7.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: Tracking is turned off so you get a nice zoom in/zoom out effect.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"
sen: It's also nearly impossible to trigger without a definitive pinch with two fingers on the screen.

title: "(491925) Firefox - Disable multitouch \"rotate\" gesture for cycling tabs"

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Problem:

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: The method FolderDescription#createExistentResourceFromHandle(IResource,IProgressMonitor) checks if the folder already exists and returns immediately if so.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: In cases where the FolderDescription has members which are not existing at that moment, that members will not be created.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Use case:

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Assume you want to create a folder and a file in that folder and use two operations for this.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I know it is not necessary to use two operations but my configuration is more complex than this example code.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: IFolder folder = ... // must not exist

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: CreateFolderOperation op1 = new CreateFolderOperation(folder,...);

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: IFile file = folder.getFile(...); // must not exist

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: CreateFileOperation op1 = new CreateFileOperation(file,...);

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: op1.execute(...);

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: op2.execute(...);

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: The execution of the op2 does not create the file because as stated above createExistentResourceFromHandle returns immediately because the parent folder of the file was created by op1.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: IMHO createExistentResourceFromHandle must check if members of a FolderDescription should be created.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I checked the code in the ganymede release and the problem should exist there too.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Is there any reason you cannot execute op1 before creating op2?

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: The basic problem is that the workspace file structure has changed since you first created the operation, so the change described by the operation is no longer valid.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: >Is there any reason you cannot execute op1 before creating op2?

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: No there is not.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: In the meantime I found a workaround in my code but I think it's very inconvenient that someone must know that op2 have to be created after the execution of op1.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: The API gave me no hint that I have to do so!

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Maybe the build of the FolderDescription could be delayed until the execution of op2.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Think about cases where the to ops have nothing in common e.g. created and executed in different plug-ins.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I'll mark this one for M4.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I think what needs to happen is that the javadoc better describes the lifecycle of these operations, and the isValid() method is tightened up so that the operation becomes invalid when the workspace changes to no longer match its recorded state.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: It is not the intention of these classes to stay in synch with workspace changes that happen independently of a shared, sequential workspace history.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Moving target as M6 has shipped.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Fixed in HEAD >20090416.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: In order to understand better what the ramifications might be of actually fixing this bug vs. better documenting the limitations and usage, I started by implementing a trial fix for the problem as reported.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: It is pretty straightforward to rearrange the code to create the child resources (the file) even if the parent exists since the operation was created.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: However, the problems occur later when you try to undo such an operation.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Since the operation \"remembered\" that the folder didn't exist when it was first created, the undo of the create file operation tries to also delete the folder.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: This means that to truly fix the bug, we'd have to change the operations so that the resource descriptions were constantly updated to deal with changes that occurred.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: So I still believe it's better to document more clearly what the intentions of the API are.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I've updated the javadoc for AbstractResourcesOperation, CreateFileOperation, and CreateFolderOperation.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: In addition, I created a stricter validity check on CreateFileOperation so that the operation will return an invalid status if portions of the resource tree already exist.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Created WorkspaceOperationsTest.test250125() to simulate this condition.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: The CreateFileOperation is valid until the CreateFolderOperation is run, at which time the file operation knows it is invalid.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: > In addition, I created a stricter validity check on CreateFileOperation so that the operation will return an invalid status if portions of the resource tree already exist.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: What I meant to say is...

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: I created a stricter validity check on CreateFileOperation so that the operation will return an invalid status if portions of the resource tree *that did not exist when the operation was created* already exist at the time of execution.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: It is expected/allowed that the containment tree already exists when the op is executed, as long they also existed when the op was created.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: verified via automated test cases that run on each build.

title: "(250125) Eclipse - createExistentResourceFromHandle forgets to create children resources"
sen: Also verified through source inspection

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Inspired by Martin Oberhuber's mail about his \"lsc\" script for counting lines in a patch[1], I though that it maybe be worthwhile to embed such thing in the Apply Patch wizard itself.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: imo using regexp should be enough here, especially due to the fact that we don't want to make any additional dependencies.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: So, my proposal is to allow to specify a regexp rule for lines that should be count as a \"real contribution\".

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: This is what first came to my head:

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
"(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: which means \"Count only lines starting with single '+' and a space.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: The line must also have at least one non-whitespace character\".

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: I think this is more/less what Martin's script does.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: All lines that match the above pattern would be sum up and the info would be displayed somewhere on the Apply Patch wizard.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: How does it sound? Martin?

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Again, I think it's a brilliant idea Martin.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: [1] sent to eclipse.org-committers

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: The info could be also shown in a patch outline view (see bug 190418).

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Excellent idea!

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Having the line counter right in the apply patch wizard would finally give us a standard way of counting lines that everybody could use easily.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: My script also ignores \"empty comment\" lines of the form

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
"(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: but that's really neglectible and I'm fine with your approach of counting any non-empty added line in the patch.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Actually, couldn't your regex even be simpler, say

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
"(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: since you don't need to check till the end of the line?

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: And actually, if the wizard counts added lines, why shouldn't it also count removed lines?

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Giving two separate numbers e.g.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: 10 lines added  20 lines removed

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: This sounds familiar to me since I've seen similar numbers in RCS files before.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: I'd guess that the regex for removed lines could just be the same as for added lines but the + replaced by a -; and, files removed entirely should contribute the entire number of lines they had before (I believe that the old contents is

sen: The \"internal\" mechanism of counting added/removed lines is very simple, it sums up all lines with '+' and '-'.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: It's awsome that this is customizeable, but when I remember right, one reason for putting this enhancement into Eclipse SDK was such that there is a \"common standard\" by which the projects count their lines in a patch.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: I think that this \"common standard\" should be as good as possible by default.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: On the other hand, having some magic like removing empty lines from the count going on in the background is perhaps a problem...

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: would it be possible to keep your current count (\"211 added / 53 removed lines\") but add an additional count without empty lines e.g.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Note that I'm only talking about empty lines here, e.g. Regex \"/-\\\\\\s*$\".

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: I agree that we cannot count empty comments here by default, because comment styles differ by language.

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Actually, it might be a good idea to have one additional kind of Regex pattern in the Preferences, which acts as a filter -- suggested tooltip behind //:

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Added Lines:    /-\\+

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"
sen: Removed Lines:  /-\\-

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"

title: "(224588) Eclipse - [Patch] Provide an information how many lines does the patch change"

title: "(437797) Firefox -  about:mozilla page is hardcoded to LTR in RC2"

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Here is the JavaDoc for IAdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class):

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Returns the class search order for a given class.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: The search order from a class with the definition class X extends Y implements A, B is as follows:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: - the target's class: X

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: - X's superclasses in order to Object

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: - a breadth-first traversal of the target class's interfaces in the order returned by getInterfaces (in the example, A and its superinterfaces then B and its superinterfaces)

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: This comment is not perfectly clear.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: In particular, it does not complete the example by explicitly listing the exact order the example classes and interfaces are returned.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I came up with a slightly richer example:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface A extends M, N

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface B extends O

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: class Y implements C, D

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: class X extends Y implements A, B

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: [The declarations for interfaces C, D, M, N, and O are trivial.]

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: The order of classes and interfaces returned by AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(X) is:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: class X

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface A

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface B

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface M

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface N

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface O

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: class Y

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface C

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: interface D

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: class java.lang.Object

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: This conflicts with the JavaDoc. The class X is the first thing returned, but it is *not* followed by \"X's superclasses in order to Object\".

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It is followed by a breadth-first list of X's interface hierarchy\", *then* followed by X's superclass Y, which is then followed by a breadth-first list of Y's interface hierarchy; and so on, up to  java.lang.Object.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Also, the JavaDoc has what reads to me as a contradiction:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: a breadth-first traversal of the target class's interfaces in the order returned by getInterfaces

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: vs.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: in the example, A and its superinterfaces then B and its superinterfaces

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: What actually happens *does* feel like a \"breadth-first\" search;

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: but that would not be accurately described as \"A and its superinterfaces then B and its superinterfaces\".

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: But maybe I'm reading it wrong....

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It might be worth discussing which is the \"preferred\" behavior: the behavior described by the JavaDoc or the behavior implemented in AdapterManager.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: In some ways having all the classes first, followed by the interfaces might make more sense than the current implementation....

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: But, then you have the whole \"backward-compatibility\" thing to worry about....

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: You are right on both counts.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: The implementation doesn't match the spec, and there is a contradiction in the spec itself.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Now the question is what do we do about it.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: - For the contradiction, I think we should stick with the breadth-first search, and delete the parenthetic comment about the example (\"A and its superinterfaces then B and its superinterfaces\")

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: - For the spec not matching the behaviour, my instinct is to \"fix\" the spec to match the implementation, to avoid the risk of breaking clients.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: This would be a very subtle change that could affect clients in unpredictable ways.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: On the other hand if there are really compelling reasons to change the implementation to match the spec, I'd be curious to hear them.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I did some research and found that the implementation did match the spec until Febuary 20, 2004, when I change the implementation.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: At that time the spec wasn't part of the API.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: The spec was later added to the API (IAdapterManager#computeClassOrder) without checking that the implementation still matched.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I'm going to do some more archeology to see if I can figure out why I changed the lookup order.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It would be interesting to know what triggered the change in behavior.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I guess the question is whether superclasses take precedence over interfaces defined lower in the hierarchy, i.e. does the implementation take precedence over the specification?

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I can see arguments for either way; but I guess I would probably come down on the side of giving specification precedence.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: So, I guess you argue further that all the interfaces could precede all the classes?

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Argh...why did I even ask? :-)

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Anyway, I don't have any use cases at the moment to argue one way or the other.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It's just that my curiosity got the better of me, after years of wondering, \"Just how does the Platform resolve which adapter to return?\" :-)

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It looks like this change was made inadvertently during a large batch of changes to add support for the adapters extension point (bug 32498).

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I think since this change was introduced accidentally, and this is a clear violation of a long-standing specification, I'm leaning towards fixing the implementation.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I noticed the spec also doesn't mention the interfaces of the target class' superclasses.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: I think the corrected spec should read:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: * <ul>

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: * <li>the target's class: X

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: * <li>X's superclasses in order to <code>Object</code>

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: * <li>a breadth-first traversal of the target class's interfaces in the order returned by <code>getInterfaces</code> (in the example, X and its superinterfaces then Y and its superinterfaces) </li>

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: * </ul>

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Note that the comment changed to \"X and its superinterfaces then Y...\" as opposed to \"A and its superinterfaces then B...\".

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Thus this clarifies how the interfaces of superclasses are considered, while fixing the contradiction in the specification of interface search order.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Created an attachment (id=122293) [details]

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Fix v01

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Created an attachment (id=122297) [details]

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Test case

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: This is a test case using your richer example

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Fix and tests released to HEAD.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Sounds reasonable.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: One tiny nit-pick though.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: The last entry in the bullet list now reads:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: a breadth-first traversal of each class's interfaces in the order returned by <code>getInterfaces</code> (in the example, X and its superinterfaces then Y and its superinterfaces) </li>

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: It might be more accurate to say:

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: a breadth-first traversal of each class's interfaces in the order returned by <code>getInterfaces</code> (in the example, X's superinterfaces then Y's superinterfaces)

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Since X and Y are not actually included in the \"traversal\".

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Thanks.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Good point, I have released this clarification to HEAD.

title: "(260502) Eclipse - AdapterManager.computeClassOrder(Class) implementation does not match IAdapterManager JavaDoc"
sen: Thanks again.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.12)Gecko/20050915 Firefox/1.0.7 (ax)

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.12)Gecko/20050915 Firefox/1.0.7 (ax)

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Firefox currently supports a wide number of stand alone e-mail applications (including it's own Thunderbird client), when an e-mail link is clicked on in Firefox.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: To the best of my knowledge it still does not support web based e-mail clients such as g-mail in this fashion.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: The idea is that if one prefers to use a web based e-mail account, they should have the option to configure firefox to log into that web based e-mail account and open a compose new message window.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: I understand this may require some colaboration with the popular web based e-mail services such as gmail and aim mail, but I think it would be worth the benifit.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Reproducible: Always

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Something like the WebmailCompose extension?

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Other enhancement requests like this have been marked as dups of bug 11459, but I think that's wrong.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: As far as I can tell, bug 11459 is a combination of a design flaw specific to Seamonkey and a tangentially related enhancement request that also applies to Firefox, and nothing is happening there.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: It's sad that mailto: links don't work for most webmail users, especially since webmail is so popular.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Webmail services can help give users programs that alter system mailto: behavior (e.g. the unofficial \"G-Mailto\" and the official \"Gmail Notifier\"), and Firefox users can download the WebmailCompose extension, but i think it would be better if this were an option in Firefox itself.

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Not going to block on this, would be good to have this generically for feeds as well, but this may have to wait for Gecko 1.9

title: "(328600) Firefox - Option for mailto: links to go to a web based e-mail client (webmail service)"
sen: Using Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.1) Gecko/20090615

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Open a new image,

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: create a layer much bigger than the image, and with a different aspect ratio.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: draw something on the drawable (using some colors)

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: make a selection selecting only some parts of your drawing

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: use the channel mixer.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: The selection looks wrong in the plugin, and the plugin can even crash.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: This is due to the fact that the selection mask is taken with gimp_drawable_get_thumbnail_data () in the preview code.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: So if the layer and the image have different size, they are streched differently.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Clearly what it is doing is bad, but what *should* it be doing?

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Should the preview follow the shape of the selection bounds, the image, or the drawable?

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: On a big image, use crop tool on right, bottom or right bottom, click on resize.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: The active picture is then little than the layer.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Using any tool with preview give a one pixel (or less ;) ) preview instead of the good one.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Compute intersection between layer and active picture could be the solution...

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: As far as I can see, there are two reasonable options, and either of them will require a substantial amount of fixing in the aspect preview code and the plugins that use it.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: (1) Show the entire drawable in an aspect preview, and mask changes using the current selection.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: (2) Show only the part of the drawable lying within the selection bounds.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: It isn't clear to me which of them is better.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Bumping to 2.4 since this is not likely to get fixed for 2.2

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Bumping to Future since this is not likely to get fixed for 2.4.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Setting back to the 2.4 milestone since it's a crash and should, if possible, be looked at before the 2.4 release.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: Fixing this might make API changes necessary.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: We need to look into this as soon as possible.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: It would help a lot if someone could attach an example XCF file to this bug report that shows the problem.

sen: This one is nasty to track down.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: The example image has dimensions 377*233, the selection starts at x=125, y=97 and extends to the lower right corner of the image.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: The preview code then calls gimp_drawable_get_sub_thumbnail on the selection mask with the following coordinates:

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: src_x: 117, src_y: 89, src_w: 268, src_h: 152

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: which unsurprisingly fails, since src_x+src_w is bigger than the selection mask width.

title: "(156905) GIMP - GimpAspectPreview doesn\'t respect the layer offset and can crash"
sen: The source coordinates seem wrong to me and originate from gimp_zoom_preview_get_source_area(), but I have not yet tracked this down.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: When images are rescaled now the GIMP always defaults to linear scaling.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Sometimes I want to do a bunch of images with cubic scaling.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: It would be handy that the scale dialog just remembered the last setting and always present that one.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: The default interpolation routine can be choosen in the Preferences dialog.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I just thought it would be easier if it just remembered the last setting, that way a newbie does not have to search trough the preferences, and it is handy if you want to scale a set of images in a different way as normally

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Jaap is right.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I didn't know about the preferences setting until I saw this bug report.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: This applies in general to options that the user can set without going into the preferences dialog: just remember the last setting, and there is no need for an entry in the preferences dialog.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: We would need an entry whether to save the last used setting, for the users who don't want this.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Michael, I don't agree with having an extra entry whether to save the setting yes or no.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: This would clutter the interface even more.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Because you then still need an entry in preferences and you need an extra entry in the scale dialog whether to save the last used setting.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Just always remembering the last setting is conceptually by far the easiest for new users.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Furthermore I think it's not really a problem if you have to change the setting now and then (In your case you also have to click once more to not save the setting).

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: And most of the times you will not change this setting.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I agree that it is convenient to be able to set a default value from the place it is used (e.g., the Image->Scale dialog) instead of having to open the Preferences and find the corresponding option.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: This is very useful for those who are not familiar with all options available in the Preferences.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: However, I disagree with the proposal that the last setting should automatically become the default: I have set the default to Cubic (I might change it to Lanczos soon) and I expect it to be used all the time.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: But from time to time, I scale up a bitmap image without interpolation.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I don't want this to become the new default and give me bad results when I scale up another image two days later.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: So if there is a way to change the default from the Scale dialog (which is probably a good idea), then it should require an explicit action from the user.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: This could be a button like \"set default\" or a checkbox \"remember this setting\" next to the \"Interpolation type\" dropdown list.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: >>Jaap is right. I didn't know about the preferences setting until I saw this bug report.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: LOL, me too.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I think the suggestion for a \"set as defaults\" button here is a good all-round solution that satisfies both camps.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: See this bug for request to deal with scaling units (percent/pixel) in the same way.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=357424

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: I think a \"set as defaults\" button would clutter the UI.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: This change remember the settings across dialog invocations.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Closing as FIXED.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: (Please reopen if you strongly disagree, but please not without a non-ugly suggestion for a GUI)

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: 2006-10-14  Michael Natterer  <mitch@gimp.org>

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Remember the settings in the scale and resize dialogs for images and layers.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Fixes bug #164995, bug #316392, and bug #357424.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/dialogs/scale-dialog.h: removed GimpScaleCallback typedef.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/dialogs/dialogs-types.h: added it here.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/dialogs/image-scale-dialog.[ch]: made the ImageScaleDialog struct private, return a GtkWidget* from image_scale_dialog_new() and use a GimpScaleCallback in the public API.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/actions/actions-types.h: #include \"dialogs/dialogs-types.h\"

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/actions/image-commands.c: changed according to image scale dialog changes. Remember the scale dialog's unit (if it is \"percent\") and interpolation type across dialog invocations.

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: Also remember the resize dialog's unit (if it is \"percent\").

title: "(164995) GIMP - Remember last scale method setting"
sen: * app/actions/layers-commands.c: remember scale and resize dialog stuff as in image-commands.c

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 1. Open a large grayscale image of your choice (e.g. larger than 2000*2000 pixels, maybe a scan result from your scanner)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 2. Use \"Tools/Color Tools/Threshold\" to apply some threshold choosen arbitrarily.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: This tool is pretty fast.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 3. Now you have a 8bit grayscale image, which actually consists only of color values \"0\" and color values \"255\".

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
"(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Converting it to a 1bit black&white image should be a very fast operation (replacing 0 (8bit) by 0 (1bit) and replacing 255 (8bit) by 1 (1bit)), but it is not:

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 4. Choose \"Image/Mode/Indexed...\", and there:

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 4.1 Colormap: \"Use black and white (1-bit) palette)\" (this should be the fastest option possible)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 4.2 Dithering: \"none\" (this should be the fastest option possible)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 4.3 Now hit \"OK\"

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 5. The conversion will work, but it will take many seconds.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: For an example image of \"2460*3483\", it takes 34 seconds on my computer (while applying the Threshold tool, which basically does the same, only needs maybe 2 seconds).

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: This slow speed is not acceptable for interactive image processing, and this slowness is not necessary at all.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Indeed it is very slow, so I will confirm this bug report.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: There is, however, a workaround.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: I found with a little experimentation that if you use the \"Optimal Palette\" option for step 4.1, then the conversion occurs in a flash, literally a fraction of a second for me.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: This happens, I think, because if you use this option, by the time the algorithm reaches the stage of actually converting the image, it has built a color histogram and \"knows\" that there are exactly two colors in the image, and can assign colors directly, without having to test whether black or white is the best match for each pixel.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Because of the existence of this workaround, I am going to lower the severity, but this *is* something that should be looked into.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Created an attachment (id=38911) [details]

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Image where to 1bit conversion is either slow or buggy (with GIMP 2.2.4)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: That's odd.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: I just tried to use your suggested workaround and was happy that the conversion was as fast one should expect.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: However, the conversion was plainly wrong, it produced an image which was just black (the input image was nearly white).

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: I'm attaching a test case image. This may be a related bug.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Do following on the atached image:

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 1. Choose \"Image/Mode/Indexed...\", and there:

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 1.1 Colormap: optimal palette (wether 2 oder 256 colors, it does not matter)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 1.2 Dithering: \"none\" (but I think it does not matter)

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Interesting -- clearly the generation of an optimal palette is not done correctly for this image.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Because this is a different issue, I am going to open a different bug report for it -- using your image as example, if you don't mind.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: In any case, I've found a solution to the original problem, I think.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: I found a very simple change that gives a major speedup when converting grayscale images to the mono palette.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: It's now at least as fast as the Threshold tool, so I'm going to resolve this bug as FIXED.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Still just as slow for RGB images, though.

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: Committed to both branches:

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: 2005-03-18  Bill Skaggs  <weskaggs@primate.ucdavis.edu>

title: "(170801) GIMP - Converting image from grayscale to black&white is painfully slow"
sen: * app/core/gimpimage-convert.c:  when converting grayscale to mono, treat the palette as gray rather than rgb, giving 	more than tenfold speedup.

sen: I'm interested in seeing the patch.
