title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: It would be usefull to add a \"Swap\" button to quickly change the aspect ratio between portrait and landscape.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: This is needed when extracting a portrait from a landscape photo.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Since there is no sign that this is going to happen for 2.4, I am bumping the target to Future.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: *** Bug 355694 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I'm going to reset this to 2.4 because I expect to implement this very soon.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: An easier and much faster user interface: swap between portrait and landscape based on mouse movement.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: You already have to move the mouse to make your selection.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: You'll likely do something that is approximately the right ratio.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: If that's closer to portrait, then portrait should get used, otherwise landscape should get used.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Another way to explain this:

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: When the user makes the selection, select landscape mode if the horizontal mouse movement is greater than the vertical mouse movement, otherwise select portrait mode.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: That's one less confusing button occupying screen space.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: That's one less button to press.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: You can work faster, with less hand/finger/wrist pain.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Albert, you completely misunderstood this.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: The point is being able to flip the aspect ratio after you have created your rectangle selection.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Really? I found Alberts comment spot on.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: It basically would eliminate the need for this kind of button, since both x and 1/x would work equivalently in the GUI.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I don't see much point in being able to flip the aspect *after* the creation of the rectangle.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: The placement of the resulting rectangle would need readjusting anyways (what is the fixed point of the rectangle while flipping?) and it sounds much more natural to me to be able to switch the orientation on-the-fly while creating the rectangle.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I'm the reporter of the wish.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Sven is right, I meant that it would be usefull to have the swap option after the creation of the rectangle selection.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I do it \"by hand\" often in that case :

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I've a landscape photo that contains an interesting flower for example.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I want to print a photo that have the same proportions as the original, but in a portrait format, more adapted to my flower.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: 1. I first \"take a shhot of the aspect ratio\" by selecting all the original landscape photo.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: 2. I freeze the aspect ratio (with the appropriate checkbox)

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: 3. I shrink the rectangle to permit him to be rotated by 90Â°

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: 4. I \"rotate\" him by taking my calculator, and calculating 1/[aspect ratio], and putting it by hand

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: 5. I've now a perfect portrait zone wich I can adapt freely to my flower; and I'm happy :)

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I don't know if adding a toolButton just to do it is a problem, but I really think I'm not the only one to do that sort of cropping on a photo.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Thanks for interest !

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Bruno

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: I agree that Albert's idea makes sense.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Have gimp assume a landscape or portrait orientation automatically depending on whether the rectangular area swept out by the user is wider or higher.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: This might only be problematic when the aspect ratio was nearly, but not exactly square, but even here the user could control the proper aspect by exaggerating the motion in the larger of the two directions.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: If a swap button is maintained as in 2.3.12, then register the initial point used to sweep out the rectangular area and use that as the anchor rather than the upper-left corner as is now used.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: It is very likely that the first point selected by the user will be a desired point and this will not be the upper-left corner unless this happens to be where they started.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: As I stated elsewhere, it would also be great if the aspect ratio was automatically set to the initial aspect of the image being loaded.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: You might provide a \"lock\" button to force the current aspect ratio to be retained upon subsequent loading of images for those times when someone wants to crop a series of pictures to the same proportions.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Maybe the current Fix button could be a toggle that switched between \"Lock\" (lock the aspect ratio - current behavior) \"Set\" (automatically set the aspect ratio for each new image and then locks it) \"Auto\"(the Set behavior combined with the behavior suggested by Albert) or \"None\".

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Having said this, I do appreciate having a toggle button at all.  Thanks.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Making this depend on the user's mouse action is not discoverable.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: There wouldn't be any way for the user to find out how to swap the aspect ratio.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: No way.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: It might make sense to determine the initial aspect ratio this way.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: But there still needs to be a button to swap it.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Comment #7 is exactly the usage scenario for this.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: This is now implemented in trunk and seems to work reasonably well.

title: "(326962) GIMP - Quick swapping between x and 1/x aspect ratio in crop and resize tool"
sen: Closing as FIXED.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen:
community has voted for. 
Examples include double-click-drag to select multiple words, triple-click, extensible hyperlink support and spell checking. 
We should also improve the current search/replace dialog. 
[Platform Text, Platform UI,SWT]

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: >We should also improve the current search/replace dialog.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Those will be minimal improvements like being able to resize the dialog.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: We won't completely redesign the dialog e.g. to provide Firefox-like search unless it is contributed by a patch.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Here is few things to look at:

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: -- Ctrl-Backspace don't work in all text editor widgets (try fields in search dialog or text fields in plugin.xml editor)

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: -- support for seaching multiline text and alow to replace into multiline text

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: -- improve usability of search dialog.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Namely, replace direction radio buttons with additional buttons like \"Find previous\", \"Replace previous\".

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: This would make getting back to accidentally skipped search match much easier.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: >-- Ctrl-Backspace don't work in all text editor widgets (try fields in search dialog or text fields in plugin.xml editor)

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Please file separate bug reports, e.g. we do not control the PDE editor - thanks.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: >-- Ctrl-Backspace don't work in all text editor widgets (try fields in search

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: The problem here is that JDT UI started to map the text editor's editing commands onto the text, combo and other widgets using TextFieldNavigationHandler.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: It would be possible push parts of TextFieldNavigationHandler down to Platform Text to provide this for dialogs around the editor but I think this is a more general issue since users then also expect the navigation commands to work in

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: wizards, Ctrl+H search pages etc.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: But this can't be adopted by JFace because they don't depend on the text editor plug-ins.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: To solve this, JFace will have to adopt/define editing commands that can be used along with widgets and would have to provide the navigation handler(s).

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Can you file a bug report against Platform UI and describe the problematic.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Please add myself to the cc-list. Thanks.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: (In reply to comment #0)

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: > extensible hyperlink support

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: I would prefer if extensive hyperlink support is much lower (ideally at the StyledText widget but if not, at the JFace level).

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: UI Forms would like to port from FormText to StyledText.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: StyledText has added many key features in 3.2 time frame with hyperlink support being the last one we need in order to port.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Dejan, you're not allone ;-)

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Feel free to add your comments to bug 156219.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: The one in text land is bug 88293.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: I'd like to throw in bug 145959 (forgive me if this doesn't apply to text editors):

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: On Windows, multi-line text boxes as used e.g. in the Run->Arguments dialog should support Return key in two ways:

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: [Return]: add CR/LF to current text box

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: [Ctrl-Return]: send Return key to parent dialog (similiar to executing the default action).

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: >I'd like to throw in bug 145959 (forgive me if this doesn't apply to text editors):

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Nothing to forgive just to ignore ;-)

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: This plan item covers Platform Text.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: You have to place your feature with Platform SWT.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Completed as of I20070327-0800.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: Some were hoping to drag source code is 3.2, perhaps they'll get it 3.3.

title: "(154119) Eclipse - Implement missing text editor productivity features"
sen: And of course, it should be optional for those who would have a man run ahead of a horseless carriage with a red flag.

title: "(238215) Firefox - Add a history window (like in Seamonkey)"

title: "(238215) Firefox - Add a history window (like in Seamonkey)"

title: "(238215) Firefox - Add a history window (like in Seamonkey)"
sen: There needs to be a way to open sidebar resources, such as the history and bookmarks, in their own window.

title: "(238215) Firefox - Add a history window (like in Seamonkey)"
sen: It's more convenient to have a single history window that doesn't take up screen real estate than having to open the history in whichever window I'm currently browsing.

sen: I like the CTRL-B and CTRL-H features of Mozilla and would like that carried over.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Version:           svn (using Devel)

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Compiler:          gcc 4.3.2 gentoo

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: OS:                Linux

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Installed from:    Compiled sources

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: If you navigate, using the file browser, to a song in the collection and select \"move to collection\", and ensure that the new file name is the same as the old file name, the song is renamed to itself (not renamed), then deleted.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: The fix for this it to make sure that songs moved into the collection are not removed during the \"move to collection\" operation.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: A patch is below.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Created an attachment (id=28078) [details]

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: bug fix

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Patch by Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com>

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This patch fixes the bug by checking if the song is in a collection before removing it after the move operation.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: A potential problem is that it may fail to remove it from a collection when moving a track from one collection to another.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Just for the record, this patch is incorrect and shouldn't be applied.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Created an attachment (id=28083) [details]

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: semi correct patch

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Patch by Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com>

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This patch fixes the problems of the above patch and gets to the heart of the issue: \"KIO::file_copy\"ing with the src and dest the same will erase the file.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This patch checks to see if the KURLs are identical before attempting to copy.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This is the same logic as used elsewhere in the modified file, so it was chosen to keep convention.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: However, it still suffers from a problem: if the KURLs point at the same location but have different string paths, for example /home/user/music/artist/song.mp3 and /home/user/music/artist//song.mp3, the test will fail. Therefore, this patch needs only a fix for this comparison problem, and then it should be ready to be applied.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Jason, you can use KUrl::cleanPath() to fix this.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: See here:

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: http://api.kde.org/4.x-api/kdelibs-apidocs/kdecore/html/classKUrl.html#05eaea3296e3778f04014bd943ac894a

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Created an attachment (id=28087) [details]

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: fixed final flaw

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Mark - thanks for the suggestion.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This patch solves the above patch's problems.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Patch by Jason A. Donenfeld <Jason@zx2c4.com>

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: \"KIO::file_copy\"ing with the src and dest the same will erase the file, so this patch checks to see if the KUrls are identical, after cleaning the urls, before attempting to copy.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Since Max is the author who wrote the Collection code (including copying/moving), I'm going to wait for his approval to this patch before committing, lest we make an oversight.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Sebr - sounds good.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I can commit it myself, hopefully, because I should have svn commit access soon enough.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: (sysadmins are usually pretty fast, no?)

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I can't test this at the moment, but I've got a couple of comments after reading the bug report and the patch:

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I didn't look up the api documentation, but using KIO::file_copy with the same source and destination url sounds like a bug in kdelibs.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: And I don't think that that is actually happening.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Because you are moving from the filebrowser, SqlCollectionLocation doesn't notice that it's dealing with a file already in the collection, and therefore doesn't use the special code that stops it from removing files from the source collection.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I am a bit surprised that the patch even works (does it?).

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: CollectionLocation should be removing the source files (because you are *moving* files) after the copy operation, which is probably when your files actually are deleted.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Max,

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This was my initial thought too...

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: that really the problem was that it was removing the source after moving.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: But then I fully mapped the flow, and I saw that that section never even gets called if sourceLocation = 0 (if it's coming

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: from a file and not another collection).

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: The logic for that part works fine, with m_tracksRemovedByDestination being correctly populated and processed.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: The thing is that removal code is never called when sourceLocation = 0.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Generally copying or moving a file into itself will delete the file; I've seen this behavior in other languages and commands, and kio doesn't appear to be an exception.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: The patch does in fact work.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Something still may be suspicious, though.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Jason, are you sure that FileCollectionLocation::removeTrack does not get called?

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I just checked the code which starts the move operation in the filebrowser, and it creates a FileColelctionLocation.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
"(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Therefore sourceLocation will always be 0, the file will be copied (and deleting a file whehn copying or moving it onto itself *is* a bug), and *CollectionLocation* will call removeTrack on the source location as part of its workflow.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Aaaaa hah! With job never being assigned, slotJobFinished is never called, and if slotJobFinished is never called,  slotCopyOperationFinished is never called, and if slotCopyOperationFinished is never called, slotFinishCopy is never

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: called, and if slotFinishCopy is never called, removeSourceTracks is never called, and if removeSourceTracks is never called, remove is never called, and if remove is never called, QFile::remove is never called.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This shouldn't happen though.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: While this works, you're right: there is something screwy going on.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Why doesn't slotCopyOperationFinished get called independently of slotJobFinished? Or is it supposed to work this way?

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: no, slotCopyOperationFinished should be called if we don't actually have to copy any tracks.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: That's a bug.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Ok. I see how it all works now.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: New patch coming soon.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Created an attachment (id=28094) [details]

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: adds movedByDestination to CollectionLocation

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: ignoredDestinations was removed, as this was no longer pertinent, since it was only used in the flow from a job event.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: movedByDestination was added to collectionLocation, since this is something all collectionlocations will potentially need to account for.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: slotCopyOperationFinished is now called if no job is created.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: Since m_removeSources is now protected and part of CollectionLocation, collections that cannot move but only copy will just set m_removeSources to false in their constructor.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: If you like this, I'm able to commit myself now.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: But I'm guessing you'll have suggestions.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: I should probably make the map private and just add another protected accessor function.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: If we go this route, I should also make the protected accessor functions virtual and add proper comment documentation.

sen: SVN commit 876841 by jdonenfeld:

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This prevents deleting a song when moving it or organizing it into its original path name by making sure the source and

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: destination are different before [re]moving.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This functionality is also potentially extended to all CollectionLocations, as now the base class has public functions to keep track of such things.

title: "(173341) KDE - song deleted when moving track into itself "
sen: This also cleans up the logic and flow quite a bit.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Can you try changing the interrupt key sequence to something else and see if it makes any difference.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: For example, change the interrupt key to Ctrl+Y

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: stty intr /-\\Y

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Then try strace, sleep, make etc. but use Ctrl+Y instead of Ctrl+C to kill them.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Chatting with ossi bringed up another very interesting usecase:

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Fact: ctrl-c doesn't work in konsole

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Next step: launch xterm and launch  strace -ttt -o konsole.trace konsole --nofork

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Now in that started konsole app, 'make' breaks just ok!

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Wonders :)

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: strace fixes things :)

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: After changing /-\\C to be /-\\Y situation is the same for /-\\Y as it was for /-\\C:

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: e.g. /-\\Y breaks 'strace', but not 'make'

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: > strace fixes things :)

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: You're doing two things there though, running Konsole with strace and also with the --nofork argument.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: To be sure which was making a difference, you'd need to:

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: 1.  Run \"konsole --nofork\" (without strace) and see if the problem is still there.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: 2.  Start Konsole normally (with no arguments), then attach to it with strace (using strace -ttt -p <pid of konsole>) and see if the problem is still there.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: The problem disappears for me with both 1 and 2, while changing the interrupt sequence has no effect just like Dmitry reported.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Any idea where to look in the code, where to set breakpoints, etc...?

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Fixed by SVN commit #771570.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: \"Fix Ctrl+C not killing applications on some users' systems.

title: "(155920) KDE - ctrl+c doesn\'t breaks foreground job"
sen: Reset all signal handlers to the default (SIG_DFL) in the child process after forking\"

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Version:            (using Devel)

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Installed from:    Compiled sources

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: OS:                Linux

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Using nightly builds from project Neon,  kdebase version 20080617+svn821478-0neon1

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: There seem to be some problems with the zoom out view.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: It doesn't layout the activities properly.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Steps to reproduce:

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 1. Zoom out.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 2. Add Activity.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Now only the newly added activity is shown, in the top left corner of the screen.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 3. Zoom in.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 4. Zoom out.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Now both the activities are shown, but not in the order they were added, and there is some whitespace around them.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: If another activity is added, this happens again, and have to zoom in and out twice to get all 3 activities to show.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Same here at openSUSE, KDE 4.1 beta 2.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: I'm using NVidia binary drivers btw, have an NVidia Geforce 6600 GT.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Just found out that the \"offset\" of the activity overview changes when you double click on the second activity.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: The same probably happens too when adding an activity.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: At this point, it's not possible anymore to use drag&drop to move to the first activity.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Only zooming out, selecting the first, and zooming in fixes it.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: yeah, that regression crept in a while ago, and it's been bugging me a lot.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: we've actually got multiple bugs in this report, it'd be nice to separate them out (but I have to leave in a minute).

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 1) adding/switching activity makes the view jump suddenly to another place (it's trying to make sure the activity is visible, and being stupid about it)

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: 2) dragging the view around to see other activities no longer works (regression! it worked before woc)

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Actually, dragging around the view does work here *except right after adding an activity*.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: I just didn't know about that functionality when I filed this report.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Adding an activity makes the view jump to another place, and also the placement of the new activity seems arbitrary.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Bug = Add activity focuses view on the new activity until zoom level changes

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: well then, let's make the title a bit clearer

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: I think add activity option (and zoom out) should be removed in the 4.1 final.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: This bug is quite big, plus there's no clear way to delete an activity.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Also,performance when zoomed out is slow as hell.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: I didn't report this issues because some of them are already reported and I thought others are pretty obvious.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: Don't get me wrong, it's a great idea, but it's current status makes it confusing, useless and buggy :S

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: performace is fine for me.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: are you using nvidia?

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: there are already people making use of multiple activities, we're not going to take that away from them.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: it'd be really really nice if this bug could be fixed somehow, though.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: > This bug is quite big

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: so huge it crashes your machine, loses dat, etc, right?

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: this is a molehill, stop making it into a mountain.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: > but it's current status makes it confusing, useless and buggy

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: so don't use it.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: we have gotten many reports of people who DO like it and are using it for day to day work.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: i suppose your desire to see this set of problems hidden overrides their productivity?

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
sen: and if we'd taken this approach in 4.0 we'd be even further behind.

title: "(164545) KDE - Add activity focuses view on the new activity"
